description: From Middle English somþyng, some-thing, som thing, sum thinge, sum þinge, from Old English sum þing (literally “some thing”), equivalent to some +‎ thing. Compare Old English āwiht (“something”, literally “some thing, any thing”), Swedish någonting (“something”, literally “some thing, any thing”).

entries.meaning: Having a characteristic that the speaker cannot specify.

examples: The baby looks something like his father.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, especially in certain set combinations) Used to adverbialise a following adjective
examples: I miss them something terrible. (I miss them terribly)

entries.meaning: An object whose nature is yet to be defined.
An object whose name is forgotten by, unknown or unimportant to the user, e.g., from words of a song. Also used to refer to an object earlier indefinitely referred to as 'something' (pronoun sense).
examples: What was the something the pilot saw, the something worth killing for?

verbs.description: something (third-person singular simple present somethings, present participle somethinging, simple past and past participle somethinged)

entries.meaning: Applied to an action whose name is forgotten by, unknown or unimportant to the user, e.g. from words of a song.
examples: He didn’t apply for it for a long time, and then there was a hitch about it, and it was somethinged—vetoed, I believe she said.
